 ABSTRACT This report presents the findings of a five-year evaluation of the First Lusaka Upgrading and Sites and Services Project. The evaluation formed part of a four-country cooperative research project supported jointly by the World Bank and the International Development Research Centre (IDRC) of Canada. The evaluation, which was conducted by a specially created Evaluation Team, within the Project Implementing Agency, included both short-term operationally oriented studies and more comprehensive socio-economic impact studies. The report contains four main parts and an Executive Summary. Part 1 discusses the Project and the political and economic context within which it evolved. The remaining parts present the main evaluation findings with respect to design and organization, efficiency of project implementation and project impact.

 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY This Executive Summary presents the main findings in the evaluation of the First Lusaka Upgrading and Sites and Services Project, and suggests lessons and issues which may be helpful in the planning of future shelter projects in East Africa. We begin with an outline of the political and economic context within which the Lusaka Project evolved, and then present a set of indicators used in the Project's evaluation. The final section discusses the possible contributions of this project and evaluation experience to future development practice. The Project Context Prior to achieving Independence in 1964, Zambia had been a junior partner in British East Africa. Lusaka had been designed as a spacious "garden city" for Europeans and Asians, with Africans being permitted to live there only while they were employed. African workers lived either on the property of their employer or in "compounds" and in most cases could not by accompanied by their families. Once employment was terminated, a worker was required to leave the city and return to his village. The housing policy called for demolition of unauthorized structures; although "illegal" communities did develop outside the city limits, no provision was made for them by local authorities. The years following Independence saw a rapid growth in Lusaka's population. This growth was due to a boom caused by high copper prices, economic diversification, administrative expansion, and a relaxation of controls on internal migration and new settlements.
 -2- Migration to the city was fueled by families coming to join spouses already established there, and by a lack of employment opportunities in the rural areas. Inevitibably, most of the new migrants moved to the squatter compounds growing up around the periphery of the city. The newly independent public administration soon found itself responsible for two separate "cities." One was the former European and Asian city with its well-planned layout and high service levels. Administration of this sector, much of which had previously been directed from London, was difficult enough because many expatriate administrators left at the inception of Independence, but at least plans and procedures had been established. The other "city" consisted of the rapidly swelling squatter areas which, after the expansion of Lusaka from 67 km2 to 360 km2 in 1970, represented about 40 percent of the total urban population. No clear guidelines existed for the development of these squatter areas. After initial attempts to continue the colonial policy of demolition, it was accepted that eradication of the settlements was neither feasible nor consistent with the official philosophy of Humanism. The situation was complicated by the fact that the quasi-legal status of the squatter areas meant they produced almost no revenue for the city to help cover the costs of their development. The incorporation of these areas contributed substantially to the decline in per capita revenue of the City of Lusaka from 3.57 Kwacha in 1965 to 1.38 Kwacha in 1972. The policy options were constrained further by the abrupt end of the period of economic growth enjoyed in the 1960s. The combined

The deteriorating economic situation made it imperative to seek less costly solutions to the rapidly worsening shelter problems. In Lusaka, as in many other parts of the world, the squatter settlements were strongholds of major political parties that became the ma^in protectors and advocates of the many thousands of people whose right to live in the city was still only partially recognized by the public authorities. Both the African National Congress and the United National Independence Party developed very strong grass roots organiza- tions and became very effective advocates of the rights of the "New Majority." The right to a house and basic services was proclaimed as one of the rewards of Independence, and stamping out housing inequali- ties and geographical segregation were seen as part of the battle against the vestiges of colonialism. After Zambia became a one-party democracy, UNIP established a very effective organizational structure, based on 25-family sections, in almost all the squatter areas. A key theme throughout the development of the Lusaka Project has been interaction between UNIP, the Housing Project Unit, and the Lusaka City Council (now the Lusaka Urban District Council). While the objective of the LCC was to integrate the project areas into the normal administrative and financial systems of the city, UNIP saw its role as ensuring that the underprivileged squatters received an equitable share
 of the rewards of Independence. The difficulties of establishing an effective cost recovery system clearly illustrate the tension between these two points of view. The equity issue was complicated further by the policy of providing housing subsidies for employees of government, local authorities and parastatal organizations. The subsidies, which originated as a colonial policy for attracting expatriate staff, continue to be highly regressive and to benefit mainly the middle and upper income groups. It is estimated that in 1978 about 44 percent of all housing subsidies to public employees were received by the 10 percent with the highest incomes, while the poorest 30 percent received only 1.8 percent of total subsidies. In total, the poorest 50 percent of workers received only 10 percent of the subsidies. 1/ It was also found that while housing subsidies represented less than 15 percent of the total employment benefit package for the poorest 30 percent of government employees, they represented over 40 percent of the benefits for the 10 percent with highest incomes. In addition to being a considerable drain on government resources, the long tradition of housing subsidies seemed to render questionable the social justice of the complete cost recovery requirement built into the World Bank-s Project designed to serve the poorest urban groups. It was estimated, for example, that many of the highest-income families were paying only about 10 percent of the economic rent for their housing. 1/ Hinh, Sanyal, Valverde and Bamberger, "Housing Subsidies in the Public Sector in Zambia," Urban and Regional Report No. 81-6, Urban and Regional Economics Division, World Bank, May, 1981.
 - 6 - The factors detailed above determined the political climate within which the Lusaka Project was planned and developed. The newly independent Zambia wished to remove the vestiges of colonialism and to give Africans the same benefits previously enjoyed by expatriates. The philosophy of Humanism reinforced this sentiment by making social and econonomic equality an important political objective. These ideals, together with urban planning traditions, created pressures to provide good, high-standard housing for everyone. Further, it was felt that housing is a right, and that standards should be determined by needs as much as by ability to pay. It was assumed that the pursuit of this policy implied subsidies for the economically weaker groups. The substantial housing subsidies provided to most public employees strengthened the case for new categorical shelter relief. The combined effects of the economic depression spanning most of the 1970s and the rapid increase in demand for public services put an increasing pressure on the resources available to the central and local government authorities. These pressures lead to the more pragmatic conclusion that lower standards must be accepted and that innovative approaches, such as squatter upgrading and sites and services, must become the basis of national housing policy. The potential contra- dictions between political objectives and the economic realities have continued to play an important part in the Project-s development. The Administrative Challenge To get an objective view of the Project-s achievements, it is necessary to appreciate the enormity of the administrative tasks it
 -7- entailed. On top of the pressures created by Independence, departure of expatriate staff, and assumption of functions previously administered from London, the Lusaka City Council and central government agencies were required to develop completely new administrative systems to handle the 40 percent of the population living in the formerly "illegal" squatter areas. Besides the pressures these events placed on an understaffed bureaucracy, the squatter areas also gave rise to strong political influences,due to the activities of the two major parties (and of UNIP after Zambia became a one-party democracy). The guiding policy of the local party organization was to obtain as many services as possible for the squatter areas from a recalcitrant public administration. Although the party structure rendered considerable assistance in mobilizing popular participation in planning and implementation, it created some opposition to the integration of the areas into the normal administra- tive structure of the City Council. Attempts to integrate the areas more closely into the LCC nexus through Ward Development Committees had to be abandoned due to the much more effective organization already existing in the UNIP local party structure. Subsequently, the local party organization has often opposed use of the stronger sanctions, such as cutting off water or evictions, to improve cost recovery. Most public housing and service programs have very poor cost recovery records. In 1979, it was estimated that the seven largest local authorities in Zambia had a total deficit of 28 million Kwacha on
 their housing accounts. 1/ The reasons for the deficit are a combina- tion of poor administration and opposition to the use of sactions to enforce payment. The fact that the Central Government is often one of the worst defaulters complicates the situation further. Poor cost recovery performance has created the widespread belief that high defaults are inevitable for housing programs and consequently make it more difficult to encourage the use of sanctions in the present Project. Despite the poor cost recovery performance of the Project, its record is much better than that of many other LUDC housing programs. The matter of land acquisition illustrates well the adminis- trative difficulties that confronted the Project. One of the major political and economic reforms of the new regime was the elimination of freehold land and the limitation of land value to its unexhausted productive capacity. Although it was assumed that the increased regulatory power of the government would greatly facilitate the process of land acquisition, most of the new legislation was still untested at the time the Project began. In fact, land acquisition proved to be the most difficult obstacle to project implementation, causing delays of more than two years in some phases of the process. In retrospect it is possible to see how the process could have been accelerated: delays were due in large part to the newness of the legislation and the HPU's inexperience in applying it. 2/ 1/ World Bank Data. 2/ These factors should not make us overlook the effect of the bureau- cratic delays which prolonged the process still further (see Chapter Five).

The Role of Shelter in National Development Strategies A number of basic policy issues emerged during the development of the First Lusaka Project, especially when the question of a possible second project arose. The issues that will be common to many country situations will be highlighted here: * Is the provision of low-cost urban shelter inconsistent with the objective of stimulating rural development? That the provision of low-cost housing will encourage economically unproductive groups to stay in the city, or worse, encourage rural to urban migration, is a common development concern. Existing evidence suggests that people migrate in search of better employment opportun- ities, rather than for improved housing. It is unlikely that the provision of housing per se will induce new migration. However, as housing projects are often quite expensive, they may use scarce resources that might otherwise be invested in rural areas. The major justification for low-cost urban shelter programs is two-fold. First, even if migration from rural areas stops completely, the demand for urban housing will continue to grow due to natural population increase. Therefore, there is a strong case for providing some basic level of shelter for the existing urban population. Secondly, a well-planned project, with
 - 21 - low standards and effective cost recovery, can almost pay for itself, and consequently need not be a heavy financial burden. * Should the provision of housing be treated as an employ- ment benefit? Until recently, most housing in Zambia has been provided at a subsidized rate as part of an employ- ment package. Consequently, higher-paid workers tend to receive higher housing subsidies. Although it may be justified in certain cases, this system is not to be recommended. The first argument against it is that it amounts to a bias against the self- employed. As housing tends to be provided at a subsidized and controlled price by employers, there has been no incentive for a private housing market to develop, and the self-employed, unless they happen to be wealthy, have no access to a housing market. The second argument against this system is that it has tended to provide high levels of housing support to upper and middle income groups and thus to produce regressive income distribution effects. 2. The Appropriate Organizational Structure for Project Implementation At both the planning and evaluation stages, the effect of setting up a special project execution unit with a considerable degree of autonomy was a key concern. There was a clear trade-off between increased efficiency in staff recruitment and project implementation on
 - 22 - the one hand, and long-term institutional development and project replication on the other. There is no simple resolution of the issue. Given the innovative nature of many prospective projects, and the cumbersome, rigid structure of many municipal authorities, project implementation may be seriously prejudiced by operating through traditional channels. It is vital that first projects succeed if they are to demonstrate the feasibility of a new approach. The Lusaka experience suggests that the following factors should be taken into consideration if a special project implementation unit is created. -Q Special units often have more flexibility in terms of salaries. If project unit staff are particularly well paid, consideration must be given to what will happen when the unit is merged with the municipality, so as to avoid the departure of staff due to lower salary scales. * Coordinating mechanisms must be set up early on to ensure a smooth transition. * Lines of responsibility for cost recovery and project maintenance must be clearly defined as these components will be under the long-term supervision of the municipality. 3. Land Acquisition In the Lusaka Project, as in many others, administrative and political complexities bearing on the process of land acquisition have been the major cause of delays, and hence of cost escalation. The
 - 23 - Lusaka experience suggests that the following issues must be considered very early in project planning: * Does the acquisition of land require any special legislation? If it does, it is essential to begin the legislative process as early as possible. * Expert advice should be sought on problems likely to arise in getting legislation approved and implemented. One common problem is that nationalization tends to lower the value of land and thus make owners less willing to sell. Another source of problems is the likelihood of political opposition from groups such as squatters, cooperatives, or small farmers who presently occupy the land. e As land acquisition is likely to be the key factor in determining the speed of project implementation, it may be useful to set up a high-level committee authorized to take expediting action. The processes of land surveying and title search can be time- consuming and require a considerable number of professional staff. In the case of Lusaka, these professionals were not available, adding to delays. A check should be made to ensure the required professionals will be available, and provision made for the training of staff or the use of expatriates or consultants, if the need arises.
 - 24 - 4. Issues Related to Project Finance Several issues arose with respect to the system of Project finance. Cost recovery proved to have an important impact on Project implementation and long-term maintenance, as well as replicability. The following are some of the issues likely to be faced in other countries as well as Zambia: * Unless the issue of existing housing subsidies is resolved very early, it is likely to give rise to political opposition to cost recovery measures. * Cost recovery problems in the Lusaka Project were due partly to administrative difficulties and partly to a lack of political will in pursuit of defaulters. Both of these liabilities are likely to be encountered in other projects. There are several ways of coping with them. These include: actively involving the community in the cost recovery process, beginning at the planning stage; gaining the support of the local political organizations which can persuade project residents to cooperate in making payments, or taking administrative steps to compensate for the lack of such support; adequate information provided to the community on the amounts and timing of payments and the reasons for them; efficient administration of payment collection, including prompt, accurate information to those who owe, and proper payment facilities, such as convenient office hours.
 - 25 - * Materials loans have been an important facet of the Lusaka Project and others, as most households have very limited access to other sources of finance. Appropriate loan estimation is a key factor here. Families must be provided sufficient resources to complete a livable dwelling unit without assuming financial burdens they cannot handle. Another issue is whether loans should be given in the form of materials vouchers redeemable only in project-related stores or in the form of funds they can spend at their discretion. In the case of Zambia, tied loans and material stores were appropriate because the unavailability of materials would have made it very difficult for families to procure needed supplies on the open market. On the other hand, this system apparently forced families to buy relatively more expensive materials than they might have wished, because these were what the project stores made available. In general, where a relatively free building materials market exists, it may be better not to tie purchases to a particular outlet. A further question is whether vouchers are preferable to cash disbursements. While there is a general suspicion that cash may be used for purposes other than house construction, it is also true that cash allows families the option of hiring labor to help in the construction process. In Lusaka, an unexpectedly high proportion of households did hire labor,
 - 26 - suggesting that consideration should be given to cash disbursements or to vouchers that could be used to hire labor. 5. Issues Related to Physical Design The first issue of physical design to provoke extensive discussion in Lusaka was that of plot size. It was apparent on the one hand that land was relatively abundant in Lusaka, so planners felt that households should be provided plots of a size appropriate both to housing construction and to the growing of their own food. On the other hand, too large a plot size would increase the cost of providing services and hasten the time when land within the city would actually become scarce. The results of the evaluation suggest that there is a considerable variation in the plot sizes families desire. Many families have not in fact used the area surrounding their house for growing food. It seems that the optimum planning option would be for a project to offer a range of plot sizes with economic pricing so that families desiring larger plot sizes would either have to pay more or be willing to live on the periphery of the city, where land is cheaper. It does not appear to be economical to provide large plots in centrally located areas merely to provide families the option of growing food only to have them decline to do so. Research has also shown that provision of large plots is not a very effective way to ensure lower population densities. Households will begin to sublet or to have additional relatives move in, so that
 - 27 - densities will increase wherever low-cost housing is constructed in prime urban locations. There was also considerable debate about the appropriate level of services. Probably the ideal design is to begin with a low level of services and to provide households with the option of upgrading at such time as they are able to afford it. To reduce costs, the Project was originally designed with many areas not directly accessible by roads suitable for vehicles. Problems arose because garbage trucks were not able to reach all areas of the Project, whereas the original intention was that households should carry their garbage to collection points on the main roads. Such an effort was to further the national goal of grassroots participation in political life and to enhance the efficiency of Project implementation. Chapter 7 of the Report describes how popular participation was effectively organized at the planning stage, where it served to promote general acceptance of what could have been a very disruptive upgrading process, but there was much less success in organizing mutual help construction. The use of community pressure was even less effective as part of the cost recovery process. The following are some of the important issues that emerged from the Zambia context but are relevant to many countries: * It is necessary to define clearly whether the community is to have an active role in decision-making as to project design and priorities or whether the objective is simply to ensure community support for decisions which have already been made. In Zambia, as elsewhere, there was a certain ambivalence on this point. If the cooperation of the community is to be sought in securing a high rate of cost
 - 29 - recovery, it must be involved in the selection of services and must be given a full understanding of the financial structure of the project. * With respect to mutual help construction, it must be decided whether this is to be a training experience in community organization, a method of reducing project costs, or an opportunity for the community to earn money which can then be spent on additional resources the community wants to develop. In Zambia, there was some confusion in this area, and in some cases residents were pressured to participate in mutual help efforts without a very clear idea of objectives. Although mutual help activities can be an effective way of providing practical training in group organization, experience suggests that it should probably not be made compulsory. Instead, community groups should be given the opportunity to participate if they so desire. The financial incentives used in the Zambia Project seems to be a useful means of encouraging families to participate. * Careful thought needs to be given to the role of the community in the cost recovery process. If there is to be community involvement, it should begin early enough to allow prospective participants some power in the project design process. It will almost never be possible to involve community members simply as collection agents, for they have no incentive to pressure defaulters to pay. As the Zambia experience showed,
 - 30 - if local political groups are involved in the collection process, there is always the possibility that they will disagree with the use of sanctions and may thus make it even more difficult to collect payments. The community can either be given a very active role, with its attendant risks, or its role can be kept to a minimum and cost recovery organized as a purely administrative task. * An issue that began to emerge in Zambia at the time the evaluation ended was that of project maintenance. As with cost recovery, experience suggests that the community must be involved in maintenance considerations at a very early stage, rather than after problems have already developed. It should be possible to instill a sense of pride and proprietariness on the part of the community so that its members will accept joint responsibility with the government for maintenance. This can be explained partly by a much lower level of unemployment than expected among project participants, and partly by the fact that most families either lacked the skills to build their own house or preferred to invest in skilled labor in order to guarantee a better quality structure. Project design should provide for both options. Families who wish to use their own labor should be helped to do so (through plans and technical assistance), but those who prefer to hire labor should also be encouraged to do so. One provision for such encouragement might be to permit part of the construction loan to be used for hiring labor. * As noted earlier, mutual help should probably not be a required part of the construction process, although it might be offered as an option for those groups who are interested. In several countries, including Kenya and El Salvador, voluntary mutual help groups have proved an effective means of

On the one hand, rentals are a potentially significant way of increasing the income of poorer households, and thus enhancing project affordability. On the other hand, there are grounds for concern that poorer sectors will be exploited, either by having to pay excessive rent, or by being forced out of the project. The Scope of the Housing Problem In December, 1974, The Government of the Republic of Zambia and The World Bank signed a loan and project agreement (Loan 1057 - ZA) designed to improve the living conditions of more than 200,000 urban Zambians. When the Project began, Lusaka was facing an acute shelter shortage. The rapid urbanization of the post-Independence decade created the need for a new approach to the shelter problem. Due to its design and level of services, public housing was unavailable to the poorest half of the population, most of which was scattered around the periphery of the city in illegal, unsafe, and unserviced shanty compounds. Between 1963 and 1974, the population of Lusaka more than tripled, rising from 123,000 to 401,000, an addition of 5,000 new households annually. During the same period, the legal housing stock of Lusaka increased by 19,434 units, less than 2,000 per year. As a result, the proportion of the city's population living in unserviced squatter areas increased from 15% to 42%. By 1974, the scale and intensity of the housing problem in Lusaka had grown to such a level that incremental policies of minor readjustment in the housing budget could no longer cope with it. To make things worse, the Zambian economy in 1974 entered the most critical stage of the post-Independence period. The price of copper, the resource accounting for 45% of government revenue and about 95% of total foreign exchange earnings, fell to a record low in the international market.
 - 38 - Trade routes through Rhodesia and Zaire were closed, and a global inflationary pressure, instigated by escalating oil prices, threatened to erode further the purchasing power of the local currency. In the span of one year, the current account balance indicated a drop from +48.5 million Kwacha in 1974 to -392.5 million Kwacha in 1975. The impact of this unprecedented economic crisis was soon felt in the housing sector. Central Government subsidies for construction of low-cost houses by local authorities were terminated. The local authorities were specifically directed to stop all housing construction programs. The World Bank Project as a Response to the Housing Crisis The staggering scale and intensity of the housing problem in Lusaka demanded a response of equal scale and intensity. The 42.1 million dollar First Lusaka Urban Development Project, aided by a 20 million dollar loan from The World Bank, promised by its scale and innovative approach to provide this response. By virtue of its design and timing, the Project held the potential for becoming a landmark for a new and more efficient urban development and management system. The Project-s most radical departure from accepted housing policy was its emphasis on developing, rather than eradicating, existing squatter settlements. The Project aimed at absorbing this marginal city population into a coherent urban services system. It would offer its beneficiaries formal leasehold titles for pieces of urban land, and such services as piped water, paved roads, health clinics, and in some cases water-borne sewerage. (Because the housing stock created by the Project cut across existing standards, enactment of the program required special legislation

This, in itself, was an important accomplishment.) The proposed Project included seven major components: acquisition of land; provision of building materials loans; the upgrading of four major squatter settlements; provision of some 4,400 plots with either communal water supply and sanitation or individual water and sewer connections (sites and services); construction of primary infrastructure, including sewer and water mains, access roads, and a garbage collection system; construction of community facilities, such as schools, markets, and health centers; and provision of technical assistance. The innovative assumption behind the Project's design was the idea that beneficiaries would be given incentives to use their own and each other's labor in the house construction and upgrading processes.  - 102 - CHAPTER SEVEN: COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT IN PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION The objectives of the Lusaka Project and the Zambian Government's national philosophy of Humanism coincided in making a priority of popular participation in decisions and activities affecting the life of the community. The kind of informal cooperation that can make self-help and mutual-help construction activity possible has always existed among residents of the squatter areas. The Project viewed this indigenous tradition as an available resource, as it viewed the squatter settlements themselves as viable starting points. This approach proved to be a major contributing factor to the Project's success. Only in sites and services areas did the conditions of community have to be established. In Project areas, 50 households form a Party Section. Sections make up a branch. Each complex has several branches, and it is within these branches that a distinct sense of local community tends to develop. The Housing Project Unit wanted to encourage communities use of individual and collective self-help labor in water-main excavation, the development of community facilities, and house construction and improvement. Ward Development Committees, comprised of community represent- atives and chaired by the local City Councillor would participate in plot allocation, help mobilize collective self-help labor for community facility construction, and shape long-range development programs to promote continued improvement of dwellings, infrastructure, and community services.
 - 103 - The World Bank negotiating team supported the idea of collective self-help but secured Government agreement that contractors would be hired, in consultation with the Bank, should the self-help approach interfere unduly with timely execution of the Project. To make the encouragement of collective self-help as productive as possible, community leaders took an active part in the processes of briefing, plot allocation, and organizing of self-help projects, as well as participating in decisions about road layout and in collection of service charges. The decisions affecting people who live in squatter compounds are made at many levels by various institutions. Where political matters are concerned, decisions are made by the Party at the section, branch, regional, or national level, or by a parallel organization at the District Governor's Office, or the Provincial Political Secretary's Development Committee. The coming of the upgrading process ushered in a new concept of development that could not adequately be implemented either by the Party or by the Ward Development Committee. Party representatives played an important role in the process of briefing beneficiaries on the nature of the upgrading process, and exhorting them to cooperate and take part in it. But to some extent, the success of the implementation depended upon the emergence of the Road Planning Groups as decision-making structures closely representative of community interests.  - 163 - The relationship between the dominant elite and the residents of Lusaka upgraded areas is not only political in nature, but also strongly social.  - 168 - CHAPTER TWELVE: IMPACT ON NATIONAL HOUSING POLICY The impact of the First Lusaka Urban Development Project on Zambian national housing policy is difficult to assess because in spite of having had three National Development Plans, Zambia cannot really be said to have a national housing policy. The plans, especially the Third National Development Plan (1979-83), do contain analyses of housing demand, but they lack a clear articulation of a delivery system and of capacity constraints, both of which are absolutely vital to the planning of a national housing policy. Thus the impact of the Lusaka Project may have to be judged by its contribution to the process of developing a national housing policy. By the time of project appraisal, there were signs that the country was ready to change its previous policy of demolishing squatter housing wherever it appeared. The Second National Development Plan (1972-76) had specifically recognized that "although the squatter areas are unplanned, they nevertheless represent assets both in social and finawcial terms. The areas require planning and services, and the wholesale demolition of good and bad houses alike is not a practical solution." Although the plan does not detail the possibilities of realization, it nevertheless states that the housing needs of the low-income urban population will be met with fully serviced plots. Despite the SNDP's lack of concrete measures for achieving its stated housing goals, its general approach was such that World Bank economic planners concluded: "Bank assistance, starting with the project in Lusaka and later projects in other cities and towns, would promote changes in national urban shelter investment, initiate squatter upgrading and accelerate the SNDP
 - 169 - site and service program The First Lusaka Urban Development Project, as envisioned by the Bank, was to be the starting point for a long range urban housing program that was to set the tone for a national housing policy. Evaluation findings indicated that, contrary to the prescribed long-range integrated approach to the low-income urban housing problem, the Zambian approach was a perfect example of reactive planning. The nation was constantly involved in reacting to crisis situations with disjointed programs whose methods and results are forgotten until the next crisis develops. Personal interviews revealed that there are some Zambian policymakers who continue to view even the Lusaka Project as a short-term solution to a temporary problem. This attitude of "disjointed incrementalism" in national planning is symptomatic of the lack of a national urban policy, without which no systematic national housing policy can be formulated. Some of the major cities have their own master plans which are static blueprints of desired land uses for the distant future, unfocussed by any definition of national objectives. And in the absence of a clear national policy of housing and urban planning goals, local authorities cannot be expected to shift radically from their customary policies. Though the chances of the First Lusaka Urban Development Project being integrated into a long range housing program appear to remain bleak at present, the impact of this project on official thinking about housing problems at the national level has been significant. Due to the demonstration effect of the Lusaka Project, it is now widely recognized and acknowledged that projects of this nature are feasible and
 - 170 - can be implemented with broad public participation and investment on the part of participant households. Even the Lusaka Project-s most severe critics accept that its per capita cost has been considerably lower than that of previous housing efforts. The Ministry of Local and Provincial Government officially acknowledged the Lusaka Project's successes in meeting the housing needs of its target population, in providing infra- structural and social facilities as well as housing, in the efficiency and effectiveness of its implementation, and in its unquestionable success from the social point of view. 1/ The demonstration effect of the Lusaka Project is confirmed by other events as well. The Kalingalinga upgrading project, financed by a grant from the West German Government, is being designed on principles very similar to those of the Lusaka Project. Even the dissimilarities, such as the creation of a revolving fund for the gradual provision of basic infrastructure are the results of lessons learned from the Lusaka Project experience. On the whole, they are young; 34% are between 26 and 30 years old, 22% are 31-35 years old, and 22% are between 36 and 40 years old. The mean age is 34.6; the median age is 31.5. The data indicate that most of the households are of a stable, nuclear family type. 86% of the household heads are married to one spouse only; 6% are married to more than one spouse, and 5% are single. The mean household size is 5.5 persons; the median size is 5.1 persons. 54% of the families have 4-6 persons; the breakdown is as follows: 21%, 4 persons; 21%, 5 persons; and 12%, 6 persons. The sites and services households seem to be politically active; 71% of the house- holds have 2 registered voters; an additional 20% have 1 voter; and 6% have 3 voters. AllPbut 4% of the household heads received some education. 59% of them had some secondary schooling; that is, they finished their education after completing Grade 6, but before entering Form 5. To mention the two extremes, 18% completed only some primary school (Grades 1-5) and 11% completed basic secondary school (Form 5). C. Place of Birth, Migrant Status The majority of the household heads (82%) were not born in Lusaka, but were born in rural towns instead. Of those not born in Lusaka, 40% were born in the Eastern province, 28% in the Northern province, and 12% in the Central province. Of those interviewed, 63% had spent their childhood in a village in Zambia, 12% grew up in Lusaka, and 10% lived in another line of rail town.
 - 187 - Prior to moving to Lusaka, 40% lived in a village in Zambia, 34% lived in another line of rail town, and 11% lived in another town in Zambia. The majority of the sites and services housing residents are not recent migrants; they have lived in Lusaka for some time. 48% migrated to the town in 1968 or earlier; an additional 20% moved in the period 1969-71, and 20% more migrated from 1972-1974. The median migration year is 1969; the mode is 1970. It appears, then, that the sites and services residents did not, as some Zambian officials speculate, migrate from rural areas to Lusaka as a direct result of the housing project. Rather, they migrated, for the most part, in the early years after the revolution, presumably to take advantage of job opportunities. The claim that the sites and services project encourages rural to urban migration is weakened by this evidence. D. First Area of Residence in Lusaka Upon arriving in Lusaka, most of the respondents (60%) lived with relatives other than their parents, 14% lived with their parents or husband, and 11% were rent-paying tenants. Many of these housing arrangements (29%) were in low cost rented housing or ina an employers compound; 20% were in squatter areas, and 16% were in unaided sites and services areas. This history of initial residence in areas other than sites and services areas is further evidence that the residents of Site 1 did not come to Lusaka for the express purpose of moving into sites and services areas; they come for jobs and endured inferior housing for a period of years prior to moving into the project area. F. Composite Based on the mean values of all variables considered so far, the typical household head can be described as a male, married to one wife only, and 35 years old. His household consists of a nuclear family unit -- him, his wife, and several children. The size of his household is 5.4 persons, 2 of whom are registered voters. He was not born in Lusaka; but in a small village in the Eastern province. His education included some formal schooling on the secondary level; he probably completed Form 3. He lived in a village immediately prior to coming to Lusaka, and migrated to Lusaka in 1969-70. Upon arriving, he lived with relatives, usually in low-cost rented housing. He inevitably found a job, or became self-employed. He then moved to a squatter area, before finally moving into the surveyed area.
 - 190 - II. WHAT THEY DO A. Employment Rates, Place of Employment, Employment History The occupational records of the heads of household show extensive employmrent backgrounds in varied, but respectable, work areas and fields. 99% are employed, including 9% who are self-employed. Many of them (35%) work in the towns' center; 25% work in a heavy industrial area, and 11% work in the Ridgeway area, which includes the Civic Center and the University Teaching Hospital. 90% of the HH heads have been working for more than 3 years; of this number, 53% have been employed for more than 10 years. The mean number of years employed is 14; the median is 10 years. B. Previous and Current Occupations The heads of household were asked to state the occupations they had pursued in 1973, as well as their current jobs. 47% of all working persons were employed in a skilled occupation 5 years ago, 17% were in professional or managerial positions, and 18% were involved in semi-skilled work. 4% were unemployed. As of 1978, 44%were in skilled occupations, 13% in pnofessional/ managerial positions, and 22% in semi-skilled positions. Only 1% were unemployed. F. Satisfaction with Allocated Plot The majority (90%) was satisfied with the allocated plot, and considered the plot allocation system fair. Most of the persons indicated that there was sufficient room on their plot for extensions to their house; 79% planned to add 2-4 rooms, if they made extensions. G. Source of Water, Before and Currently When questioned about the water supply, 98% of the residents said they received water from a private tap, and 97% responded that they were satisfied with this system. In contrast with this, only 14% of these people had received water from their own private tap in their previous area of residence -- most of them (74%) had obtained water from a shared tap, and 12% had relied on wells. H. Sanitary Facilities, Before and After The data on sanitary facilities are also impressive. In their previous houses, 68% of all persons used shared pit latrines; at the time of interview, 91% of all persons had private pit latrines. As would be expected, most of those questioned (74%) were satisfied with their sanitary facilities in the sites and services housing. The direct testimonies of satisfaction with the plot, pos- sibilities for extension and improvement, and with water and sanitary facilities are in direct contrast with the belief of some Zambian officials that the level of satisfaction was low due to the "shoddy quality" of services provided.
 - 197 - Through the sites and services project, low income residents have acquired good quality housing at reasonable cost. The houses are of adequate size, and there is space for extension if the residents so desire. The construction materials, water supply, and sanitary facilities are superior to those available in squatter housing. Thus, the Project has had a substantial role in bettering the standard of living of its low income participants.

doc.abstracts: This report presents the findings of a five-year evaluation of the First Lusaka Upgrading and Sites and Services Project. The evaluation formed part of a four-country cooperative research project supported jointly by the World Bank and the International Development Centre of Canada. The evaluation, which was conducted by a specially created Evaluation Team within the Project Implementing Agency, included both short-term operationally oriented studies and more comprehensive socioeconomic impact studies. The report contains four main parts and an executive summary. Part I discusses the project and the political and economic context within which it evolved. The remaining parts present the main evaluation findings with respect to design and organization, efficiency of project implementation and project impact.
